items.title: Free online virtual reality tool helps people tackle public speaking nerves
items.author: Dr Chris Macdonald, Dr Matteo Cella, Dr Kim Smallman
items.summary:
- A free online platform helps users practice public speaking in front of virtual audiences to reduce anxiety.
- Developed by Dr Chris Macdonald at Cambridge University, the platform incorporates exposure therapy techniques to confront fears.
- Users can practice in various VR settings, from small classrooms to stadiums of 10,000 spectators, with the option for distractions.
- A study showed that anxiety among adolescent users dropped significantly after using the VR platform.
- Future research plans include more extensive trials with control groups to better evaluate efficacy and user impact.

items.title: How Sea Power Gained Gamer Fans Through Disco Elysium
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Sea Power collaborated on a soundtrack for the critically acclaimed game Disco Elysium, released in 2019.
- The game's narrative centers around an alcoholic detective, resonating with themes in Sea Power's music.
- Many songs in the game were reworked from Sea Power's previous tracks, creating an atmospheric soundscape.
- The partnership increased Sea Power's visibility and listener base, introducing them to a new audience of gamers.
- The band will perform songs from the game on an upcoming mini tour titled Soundtracks Live, catering to Disco Elysium fans.

items.title: Writers Respond to AI-Generated Short Story
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Writers share their reactions to a short story written by an AI model, praised for its creativity by OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman.
- Jeanette Winterson finds the AI's metafictional piece about grief to be 'beautiful and moving'.
- Nick Harkaway critiques the emptiness of AI writing and discusses copyright issues regarding AI's training data usage.
- Tracy Chevalier expresses skepticism about AI's ability to capture the essence of human creativity.
- Kamila Shamsie reflects on the potential impact of AI on writing, noting the quality of the AI story while raising concerns about copyright and creativity's future.
- David Baddiel comments on the cleverness of the AI story, likening it to an exploration of machine emotions through a human lens.

items.title: The best rice cookers for gloriously fluffy grains at home: nine tried and tested favourites
items.summary:
- Most Britons cook and eat rice a few times a week, but cooking it can be tricky.
- Rice cookers help achieve perfectly cooked rice, adjusting time and water ratios automatically.
- The article reviews nine rice cookers, highlighting their features and performance.
- The best overall rice cooker is the Yum Asia Bamboo rice cooker, with advanced settings and even cooking.
- Other top choices include the budget-friendly Russell Hobbs large rice cooker and the multifunctional Ninja Foodi 8-in-1 PossibleCooker.
- Testing involved cooking different types of rice, evaluating taste, texture, and safety.

items.title: Tesla warns Trump trade war could harm US electric car companies
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's Tesla has warned the US government that Trump's trade war may expose it to retaliatory tariffs affecting all US automotive manufacturers.
- In a letter to US trade representative Jamieson Greer, Tesla advocated for fair trade and urged the government to avoid inadvertently harming US companies.
- Tesla highlighted the need for USTR to consider the downstream impacts of proposed trade actions, referencing past disputes that led to increased tariffs on US electric vehicle exports.
- The company expressed concerns about the significant tariffs Trump's administration has imposed that affect global vehicle and parts production.
- Tesla's share price has dropped over one-third in a month due to fears of customer backlash against Musk and his political associations.
- Trump indicated he is purchasing a “brand new Tesla” while blaming boycotts on a “radical left.”
- BMW reported a 37% decline in net profits in 2024 due in part to the impact of US tariffs, forecasting a competitive environment and geopolitical challenges ahead.

items.title: Daveed Diggs’ sci-fi rap trio Clipping: ‘We are at war all the time. It’s one of the great tricks of capitalism’
items.author: Daveed Diggs, William Hutson, Jonathan Snipes
items.summary:
- Daveed Diggs, winner of a Tony Award, explores sci-fi themes in underground rap as part of the trio Clipping.
- Their new album, [Dead Channel Sky](https://clppng.bandcamp.com/album/dead-channel-sky), addresses issues like racial violence and capitalism.
- The trio's music avoids first-person lyrics, allowing listeners to engage more personally with the characters in their songs.
- They critique mainstream hip-hop for its narrow definitions of authenticity and linear storytelling.
- The album features diverse musical styles, drawing influences from various dance sub-genres like big-beat and acid house.
- Diggs cites William Gibson's [Neuromancer](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/nov/26/william-gibson-neuromancer-book-club) as a major influence, framing their work within a critique of modern corporatism and its impact on society.
- The album’s storytelling touches on colonialist wars as an analogy for contemporary societal issues, with reflections on how technology facilitates exploitation.

items.title: What could Apple’s high court challenge mean for data protection?
items.author: Dan Milmo
items.summary:
- Apple is challenging a UK government demand to access encrypted customer data in a high court hearing in London.
- The Home Office's request involves Apple's Advanced Data Protection service, which encrypts data on their cloud.
- Apple removed its strongest data protection tool from the UK last month to comply with UK regulations.
- Human rights groups are joining Apple's challenge against the Home Office, citing concerns about backdoor access to personal data.
- Legal experts suggest that the government's requests must align with human rights protections.

items.title: Release of technology secretary’s use of ChatGPT will have Whitehall sweating
items.summary:
- Technology Secretary Peter Kyle's use of ChatGPT was revealed through a Freedom of Information Act request.
- The disclosure has caused frustration among ministers, indicating potential repercussions for officials' use of chatbots.
- Experts express surprise at the granting of access to Kyle's ChatGPT queries, suggesting this sets a new precedent for future requests.
- There is speculation on whether similar disclosures could be made regarding ministerial Google searches.
- The distinction between personal and official use of devices remains ambiguous, affecting what information can be withheld.

items.title: Intel shares surge as investors cheer appointment of new CEO Lip-Bu Tan
items.summary:
- Intel shares rose nearly 15% following the appointment of Lip-Bu Tan as CEO.
- Tan replaces Pat Gelsinger, who was ousted three months prior due to disagreements on strategy.
- Intel faces challenges, including market share losses and a significant drop in stock value over the past five years.
- Analysts see potential in Tan's industry relationships to improve Intel’s contract manufacturing business.
- Tan's previous experience and tenure on the board may aid in the turnaround process, though it is expected to take years.

items.title: How to end your phone addiction once and for all | Letter
items.author: Sarah Sorensen
items.summary:
- The Guardian published many articles on smartphone usage concerns.
- Emma Beddington’s article highlights risks of smartphones.
- Suggests extreme solution of destroying devices to regain freedom.
- Advocates for living phone-free and accessing services without smartphones.

items.title: Crypto reaps political rewards after spending big to boost Trump
items.summary:
- The US president hosted crypto leaders at the White House, following major political wins for the crypto industry.
- Trump signed an executive order to create a 'strategic reserve' of cryptocurrency, promoting a friendly approach towards the industry.
- US oversight agencies dropped investigations into major crypto companies and fraud charges were dismissed against a Trump meme coin entrepreneur.
- Trump renewed his pledge to make the US 'the bitcoin superpower' and welcomed crypto investment in politics, with donors contributing $11 million to his inauguration.
- Despite political support, the price of Bitcoin is down 13% since the start of the year, reflecting broader stock market trends amid economic uncertainty.

items.title: Careless People by Sarah Wynn-Williams review – Zuckerberg and me
items.author: Sarah Wynn-Williams
items.summary:
- The book parallels Douglas Coupland’s Microserfs, depicting youthful idealism at Facebook in 2011.
- It narrates experiences at Facebook, including a seizure incident ignored by superiors.
- Zuckerberg's early political interactions and ambitions reveal his naiveté and missteps during Trump's campaign.
- The book critiques Facebook’s role in spreading misinformation leading to real-world consequences.
- It highlights Zuckerberg’s perceived incompetence, including his disconnect from political realities and office culture.
- Sheryl Sandberg’s influence and Wynn-Williams’ experiences of workplace harassment are central themes.
- Wynn-Williams left Facebook in 2018, questioning improvements in the office culture as Zuckerberg sought to revitalize it with 'masculine energy'.

items.title: Meta puts stop on promotion of tell-all book by former employee
items.author: not given
items.summary:
- Meta secured an emergency arbitration ruling to halt the promotion of the book "Careless People" by former employee Sarah Wynn-Williams.
- The book presents a critical portrayal of Meta and its executives, including CEO Mark Zuckerberg.
- The ruling emphasized that Meta faced "immediate and irreparable loss" without emergency relief.
- The ruling directs Wynn-Williams to stop promoting the book, although it did not mandate any action from the publisher, Macmillan.
- Meta's spokesman stated the ruling confirmed that the book is "false and defamatory."

items.title: Wanderstop review – a wonderful break from the pressure to win
items.author: Davey Wreden
items.summary:
- Wanderstop is developed by Davey Wreden, known for The Stanley Parable and The Beginner’s Guide.
- The game features a fallen warrior managing a tea shop, reflecting themes of burnout and recovery.
- It focuses on gentle gameplay without the pressure to progress or win, encouraging a relaxing experience.
- Players engage in tea-making, garden upkeep, and character interactions without the grind of traditional games.
- The narrative and gameplay create a harmonious experience that emphasizes rest and healing.
- Completion time is about 12 hours, but the game invites replay for exploration and deeper engagement.

items.title: Parents should stop children gaming on Roblox if they are worried, says CEO
items.author: David Baszucki
items.summary:
- Roblox’s CEO, David Baszucki, advises parents to prevent children from using Roblox if they are uncomfortable with it.
- The platform faces concerns over bullying, grooming, and exposure to harmful content, particularly among users aged 8 to 12.
- Roblox reports an average of over 80 million players daily in 2024, with roughly 40% under 13.
- Baszucki emphasizes the company's commitment to user safety, including monitoring communications and using advanced AI for behavior analysis.
- Changes to mitigate risks include banning under 13s from direct messaging and specific chat experiences.
- Roblox's valuation is currently at $41 billion, with its virtual currency Robux integral to its business model.

items.title: Young people: what rules around smartphone use should be put in place for children?
items.summary:
• Article seeks input from individuals aged 18-24 about their childhood smartphone and social media experiences.
• It invites readers to share their thoughts on allowing access to smartphones/social media for their children and suggested rules.
• Readers can contribute their stories anonymously through a provided form.
• The article emphasizes the importance of securing personal data and offers links to the terms of service and privacy policy.

items.title: Campaign to bar under-14s from having smartphones signed by 100,000 parents
items.summary:
- An online campaign, Smartphone Free Childhood, has gained 100,000 signatures to restrict smartphone ownership for children under 14.
- The campaign launched a parent pact in September, committing to withhold smartphones until children finish year 9 and keep them off social media until age 16.
- The most support comes from Surrey with 6,370 signatories, followed by St Albans aiming to become Britain's first smartphone-free city for under-14s.
- Notable celebrity supporters include Paloma Faith, Benedict Cumberbatch, and Emma Barnett.
- Ofcom reports that 89% of 12-year-olds have smartphones and half of children under 13 use social media.
- Concerns arise that a full ban might be impractical while some experts emphasize the need for reform in social media practices.

items.title: AI should replace some work of civil servants under new rules, Keir Starmer to announce
items.summary:
- Keir Starmer plans to replace government officials' work with AI where possible, claiming it can do tasks better and faster.
- Over £45bn could be saved through digital methods before AI introduction, with 2,000 new tech apprentices planned for civil service.
- The initiative has caused concern among unions about job safety and morale due to historical criticism of civil servants.

items.title: Apple to appeal against UK government data demand at secret high court hearing
items.summary:
- Apple is appealing a UK government demand for access to customers' encrypted data.
- The appeal will be heard in a closed session of the investigatory powers tribunal on 14 March.
- The Home Office's order requires companies to provide user data in national security situations.
- Apple's advanced data protection program prevents even the company from accessing user data.
- Apple argues that creating a backdoor would compromise user privacy and security.
- There is a media campaign advocating for the hearing to be public due to its significance to civil liberties.

items.title: Pokémon Go maker to sell games to Saudi-owned company for $3.5bn
items.summary:
- Niantic Labs to sell its video game division to Saudi-owned Scopely for $3.5bn.
- The deal allows Niantic to focus on geospatial technology after struggling to replicate the success of Pokémon Go.
- Saudi Arabia's ambitions to be a global gaming hub are advanced with this acquisition.
- Niantic will distribute an extra $350m to its equity holders and spin off its AI business into Niantic Spatial.
- Niantic Spatial will be funded with $250m from Niantic and Scopely, retaining all original investors as shareholders.
- Saudi Arabia aims to invest nearly $38bn in the gaming industry through its Savvy Games Group, which is a major investor in Nintendo.

items.title: From Neva to A Highland Song, the Baftas are a reminder of how creative games can be
items.summary:
- The 2025 BAFTA Games Awards nominations were recently announced, highlighting creative aspects of video games.
- Notable nominees include *A Highland Song* and *Still Wakes the Deep* for best British game, and *Hellblade II* with 11 nominations overall.
- The awards ceremony will take place on April 8, 2025, hosted by comedian Phil Wang, featuring a mix of indie and large-scale games across various categories.

items.title: The best steam cleaners and mops for a sparkling home, tested
items.summary:
- Steam mops effectively clean hard floors and freshen carpets using steam.
- Simple steam mops start at less than £50; higher-end models can cost up to £180.
- The top steam cleaners were tested over four weeks on various surfaces including floors and tiles.
- Best overall cleaner: Kärcher SC3 EasyFix Extra (£164.99).
- Best combination cleaner: Vax Steam Fresh Total Home (£160).
- Best steam mop: Vileda Steam Mop Plus (£74.99).
- Best for grimy floors: Shark S8201UK Steam and Scrub (£159).
- Handheld budget option: Bissell SteamShot (£50).

items.title: Josh Berry: the 10 funniest things I have ever seen (on the internet)
items.summary:
* The article discusses the internet's humorous content as envisioned by Josh Berry.  
* It highlights 10 comedic moments from the internet, including sketches and performances.  
* Featured comedic acts include Alan Partridge, Johnny Vegas, Eddie Murphy, TJ Miller, Jimmy Carr, and Bo Burnham among others.  
* Each entry is accompanied by a video link to the respective performance or moment mentioned.  
* The author reflects on the nature of humor and the impact of comedy in the current digital landscape.  
* Josh Berry’s show, Best Man, will be performed at the Sydney comedy festival in April.

items.title: ChatGPT firm reveals AI model that is ‘good at creative writing’
items.author: Sam Altman
items.summary:
- OpenAI has developed a new AI model recognized for its capability in creative writing.
- CEO Sam Altman expressed being 'struck' by the model's output in a post on X.
- Ongoing legal battles are highlighted regarding AI training on copyrighted material, with notable lawsuits against OpenAI and Meta.
- The UK government is proposing AI companies be allowed to train on copyrighted material without permission.
- Altman provided a metafictional story as an output example, showcasing the model's creative abilities.

items.title: Delays and uncertainty dog Intel’s dream of Rust belt manufacturing hub
Expelled! review – turning the tables on the private school class hierarchy
items.summary:
- The game follows Verity Amersham, a scholarship student accused of a serious crime at an elite school.
- It explores themes of class inequality, with Verity's background hindering her chances against the school's headmistress.
- Players have to solve puzzles and make choices to prevent Verity's expulsion and uncover school secrets.
- The gameplay involves multiple playthroughs to understand character motivations and plot twists.
- Set in 1922, the story touches on the effects of the British Empire and its class system.
- Verity's character evolves from victim to manipulator to survive in a system that values ruthlessness.
- The game was released on March 12, 2025.

items.title: Trump calls Tesla boycott ‘illegal’ and says he’s buying one to support Musk
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Donald Trump claims he will buy a new Tesla to support Elon Musk amid a boycott by what he calls 'Radical Left Lunatics'.
- The announcement followed Tesla's worst share price fall in nearly five years, decreasing by 15%.
- Trump plans to label violence against Tesla showrooms as domestic terrorism in response to protests.
- He stated he would personally choose a red Model S during a press conference outside the White House.
- Trump's assertion that the boycott is 'illegal' contradicts a 1972 Supreme Court ruling protecting the right to protest against private businesses.
- The group TeslaTakedown, organizing protests, emphasizes that peaceful protest is not domestic terrorism.

items.title: ‘A lot worse than expected’: AI Pac-Man clones, reviewed
items.author: John Hester, Justin Martin, Jimmy, Stiven, Matt, ₿lackthorne, Rich Pelley
items.summary:
- Microsoft and Google have developed models that generate video games.
- Users created Pac-Man clones using xAI's Grok chatbot, often with mixed results.
- Feedback from various users highlights ease of use but also significant bugs in the gameplay.
- Overall scores for the Pac-Man clones varied, with many getting 3 stars for their attempts, while some received lower evaluations.

items.title: Where has the left’s technological audacity gone? | Leigh Phillips
iPhone 16e review: Apple’s cheapest new phone
items.summary:
- The iPhone 16e is priced at £599 (€699/$599/A$999), being Apple's most affordable new smartphone.
- It features a design similar to the iPhone 14, with the latest chips of the iPhone 16, an all-screen design, and a lightweight aluminium body.
- The device lacks a camera control button, has a 6.1-inch OLED screen, and supports the Apple 5G modem but only Wi-Fi 6.
- There is no MagSafe functionality and it comes only in black or white.
- Battery life is noteworthy, lasting 52 hours of general usage, which is longer than the iPhone 16.
- Specifications include a 6.1in Super Retina XDR display, A18 chip, 8GB RAM, up to 512GB of storage, a single 48MP rear camera, and IP68 water resistance.
- Environmental efforts are highlighted with over 30% recycled materials used in its construction and a repairability score of 7 out of 10 by iFixit.

items.title: Elon Musk claims ‘massive cyber-attack’ caused X outages
Trump says US in talks with four groups over TikTok sale: ‘It’s up to me’
items.summary:
- Donald Trump announced the US is in discussions with four groups to acquire TikTok.
- A US law requires TikTok to divest from its Chinese owner, ByteDance, to avoid being banned.
- Trump stated: 'It could be' a deal soon, without specifying the groups involved.
- The law banning TikTok took effect on January 19 due to national security concerns.
- TikTok briefly shut down in the US and was removed from app stores but resumed service in February after negotiations.
- Potential buyers include Frank McCourt’s Project Liberty, Microsoft, Oracle, and a group led by internet personality MrBeast.

items.title: Long live Joyce Carol Oates’ Twitter account: the only pure space left on this hell site
items.summary:
- Joyce Carol Oates, 86, is known for her unique and insightful tweets, particularly her take on Halloween in 2021.
- She has posted over 170,000 tweets, covering various topics from politics to whimsical thoughts.
- Her tweets often spark confusion and amusement while avoiding mainstream culture wars.
- Many consider her one of Twitter's greatest posters, bringing genuine joy amidst the platform's chaos.
- Oates' candidness and creativity in her tweets offer a fresh perspective and a break from traditional discourse.

items.title: The making of Elon Musk: how did his childhood in apartheid South Africa shape him?
items.summary:
- Elon Musk spent his final school years in the 1980s at Pretoria Boys High School in South Africa during apartheid.
- The article highlights the affluence of white suburbs amid national turmoil, with insights from Musk's classmates.
- Musk has expressed criticism of South Africa's racial policies, claiming they target white minority rights and calling for reforms.
- Under Trump, Musk's views may hold greater influence, particularly regarding land reform and economic policies in South Africa.
- The piece delves into Musk's troubled schooling experiences and his upbringing's role in shaping his current beliefs and political stances.

items.title: Are AI-generated video games really on the horizon?
items.summary:
- Microsoft introduced Muse, a gameplay ideation tool to streamline game development by generating mock gameplay videos.
- Muse is trained on gameplay data from Ninja Theory's Bleeding Edge, aiming to reduce the time required to prototype game ideas.
- Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer suggested Muse might help preserve classic games, but it currently can't create playable games, only footage.
- Previous projects like Google's GameNGen showed inconsistency in AI-generated gameplay, a challenge Muse aims to address.
- Experts express skepticism about Muse's purpose for game developers, noting it currently doesn't resolve core development issues.
- Future potential exists for AI-generated games, but substantial advancements are required before that becomes a reality.

items.title: Selfies, tickets and perfect angles: tourism and smartphones in Barcelona – in pictures
items.author: Stefan Nieland
items.summary:
- Park Güell requires ticket bookings often a week in advance to manage visitor flow. 
- Selfies and photos are a prominent aspect of tourist activities in iconic sites such as the Sagrada Familia. 
- Thousands gathered at Passeig de Gràcia to witness Barcelona's Christmas lights and capture the moment. 
- Tourists actively take pictures at various popular locations throughout Barcelona, from murals to festive decorations. 
- Observations raise questions about whether the pursuit of the perfect photograph detracts from genuine experiences in these moments.

items.title: The left needs to abandon its miserable, irrational pessimism
items.author: Aaron Bastani
items.summary:
- Global life expectancy has increased from an average of 40 years a century ago to 73 years today.
- Only 19% of Americans believe their children will have better lives than they do, reflecting a pervasive sense of pessimism.
- The article argues against irrational pessimism on the left, emphasizing the potential benefits of technological advancements alongside the importance of Universal Basic Services.
- Optimism in sectors like Silicon Valley contrasts with the disillusionment prevalent among others, questioning the belief that more technology can address societal issues.
- The author promotes meaningful optimism rooted in political vision and collective action, rather than blind faith in technology.

items.title: Twins! Rivals! Clones! Hollywood is doubling down on dual roles
items.summary:
- Dual roles in films have primarily been used for comedic purposes in the past.
- This year sees a rise in serious dual roles with notable performances from Robert De Niro, Michael B. Jordan, and Robert Pattinson.
- Technological advancements, like AI-driven deepfakes and motion control, are making creating dual roles more feasible and cost-effective.

items.title: What are smartphones stealing from us? When mine was taken away, I found out
items.author: Alexander Hurst
items.summary:
- The author reflects on their experience as an extra on a film set, where smartphones were not allowed.
- They enjoyed genuine interactions with fellow extras and found relief from constant connectivity.
- The article discusses a growing backlash against smartphone addiction, highlighting trends such as teenagers opting for 'dumb' phones.

items.title: Readers reply: What is the biggest missed opportunity in history?
items.summary:
- Readers discuss historical missed opportunities, including EMI passing on The Beatles.
- The impact of the Blair government's policies on social housing is highlighted.
- Concerns are raised about ignoring climate change warnings from scientists.
- The effect of the internet on misinformation is noted, along with suggestions for accountability.
- Bernie Sanders not receiving the 2016 Democratic nomination is mentioned as a significant missed chance.
- Historical events, such as France's inaction during Hitler's remilitarization of the Rhineland, are discussed as missed opportunities.

items.title: Skype shutdown surfaces sweet memories: ‘I proposed marriage’
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Microsoft announced the shutdown of Skype, set for 5 May 2025, marking the end of an era for the video chatting platform.
- Experts noted Skype's neglect by Microsoft as a precursor to its demise, citing lack of integration with Microsoft's other services.
- Users shared nostalgic memories, including proposals and connections made possible through the platform, highlighting its role in maintaining long-distance relationships.
- Tributes celebrated the impact of Skype on personal and professional lives, particularly during times of isolation or geographical separation.
- Creative expressions inspired by Skype, such as music compositions and personal anecdotes, resonated among former users.

items.title: Who bought this smoked salmon? How ‘AI agents’ will change the internet (and shopping lists)
items.summary:
- OpenAI's new AI agent, Operator, can autonomously shop online using a grocery list.
- Operator is accessible to UK users and can complete tasks like searching and ordering items from supermarket websites.
- AI agents are considered the next step in technology, helping automate mundane tasks, though they are still experimental.
- Limitations include needing user intervention for login and handling sensitive information.
- Users experienced mixed results with grocery orders, sometimes receiving incorrect items.
- The technology aims to evolve, enabling agents to perform more tasks and learning user preferences over time.

items.title: Internet shutdowns at record high in Africa as access ‘weaponised’
items.summary:
- Digital blackouts reached a record high in 2024 in Africa, with 21 shutdowns in 15 countries.
- This surpasses the previous record of 19 shutdowns noted in 2020 and 2021.
- Shutdowns primarily occurred in response to conflicts, protests, political instability, and elections.
- Countries involved included Comoros, Guinea-Bissau, Mauritius, Burundi, Ethiopia, Equatorial Guinea, and Kenya.
- The trend of increasing shutdowns was noted globally, with 296 across 54 countries in 2024.
- The African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights passed a resolution in March 2024 to address this issue, but shutdowns have continued.

items.title: Stalked: how a relentless campaign of online abuse came to derail one woman’s life
Skype got shouted down by Teams and Zoom. But it revolutionised human connection
items.author: John Naughton
items.summary:
- Microsoft has decided to terminate Skype on May 5, 2025, moving users to Microsoft Teams.
- Skype was founded in 2003 and became the first successful VoIP service, boasting 100 million users by 2006.
- Despite being revolutionary for digital communication, Skype was sidelined by Microsoft in favor of Teams, especially during the pandemic when remote work surged.
- Skype's introduction significantly transformed telephony, enabling free global communication, which was previously expensive and limited under traditional phone systems.

items.title: Virtual reality in solitary confinement isn’t a Black Mirror episode. It’s happening in California
items.summary:
- Samantha Tovar, known as Royal, experiences virtual reality (VR) for the first time in a California prison, providing a mental escape from solitary confinement.
- The seven-day intensive VR program includes immersive scenes from daily life and adventure, aimed at processing emotions through art exercises.
- Creative Acts, the organization behind the program, uses arts as a resource for behavioral change among participants. Plans to expand beyond California are hampered by funding issues.

items.title: Meet-cutes, boys’ bedrooms and buff bodies: meet the people behind TikTok’s viral vox pop accounts
items.author: Rachel Coster, Jeremy Bernstein, Aaron Feinberg, Victor Lee, Simon Squibb, Mark Langowski
items.summary:
- Rachel Coster's TikTok account, @boyroomshow, explores boys' messy bedrooms and domesticity issues.  
- Comedian Coster conceptualized the show during the Hollywood actor's strike, now with 40 episodes highlighting boys' often neglected living spaces.  
- Meet-cutes NYC, run by Aaron Feinberg, Jeremy Bernstein, and Victor Lee, interviews couples about their relationships, now boasting 1.8 million followers.  
- The group is expanding to London and plans to hire interviewers in Europe, having captured around 7,000 couples' stories.  
- Simon Squibb uses TikTok to help people achieve their dreams, having invested in 79 businesses, proving the power of social media for positive impact.  
- Mark Langowski asks fitness questions on the street, revealing compelling stories behind everyday people's workout routines.

items.title: ‘Major brand worries’: Just how toxic is Elon Musk for Tesla?
items.summary:
- Tesla registrations in Germany fell 76% to 1,429 last month amid rising electric vehicle registrations overall.
- Elon Musk's support for Germany's Alternative für Deutschland has tarnished Tesla's brand image.
- Tesla's valuation is closely tied to Musk's political activities, raising concerns over potential long-term effects on sales and brand reputation.
- Activists have staged protests against Musk and Tesla, indicating growing public dissatisfaction.
- In January 2025, Tesla reported a sales decline, with global projections suggesting a need for customer retention in an increasingly competitive market.

items.title: Martha Lane Fox Critiques Elon Musk and Diversity Issues on International Women’s Day
items.author: Martha Lane Fox
items.summary:
- Martha Lane Fox expresses strong criticism of Elon Musk, calling him 'horrendous' and highlighting concerns over his influence on diversity initiatives.
- The US government under Trump has rolled back diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, impacting many companies.
- Fox warns that neglecting diversity will lead to economic and social inequality, emphasizing that companies with diversity are better positioned for business success.
- She notes that progress in gender equality in the workplace is stagnating, with the UK now at its lowest ranking for workplace gender equality among large economies in a decade.
- Fox stresses the importance of keeping diversity issues visible and reports on progress, instead of relying solely on government regulation for targets.

items.title: Trump to host crypto leaders after creating strategic reserve of bitcoin
items.summary:
- Cryptocurrency industry leaders to meet with Donald Trump to discuss making the U.S. the "crypto capital of the world".
- Trump signed an executive order creating a strategic reserve of cryptocurrency, set to include bitcoin.
- Key attendees include Michael Saylor, Zach Witkoff, and Vlad Tenev, with discussions focused on the strategic reserve's details.
- The reserve will utilize forfeited bitcoin from federal assets, as stated by White House crypto czar David Sacks.
- Participants express optimism for collaborative regulation under the current administration, with various views on the included cryptocurrencies.
- The meeting aims to clarify regulatory scrutiny and the approval process for exchange-traded funds.
